reviews:
If you find yourself on either Bslboa Island or the Balboa Peninsula, you HAVE to take the ferry across. It seems like you never have to wait, as there are 2 or 3 running all day. Inexpensive little thrill, walk on, bicycle, or drive your car.

A few bucks to have your car taken over to the pennesula, a ride back in time when we used to rent a house on the island for the summer...

Walked from hotel to Balboa Island for shops/restaurant then took the ferry across ($1 for pedestrians) to Balboa Peninsula where we continued walking (0.5 mile) to The Wedge to soak in the beach sun and relax on the beach.

My family has been riding this ferry a long time. Since the 50's for me. Always fun and cool. We were lucky and were able to drive on with only a couple of minutes wait. One pays on the Ferry, so no need to get tickets ahead of time. There are clean public restrooms right by the loading dock, very convenient.

Love that you can bike, float, or take your car across in quicktime! A perfect way to get inexpensively from shore to shore!

Apple pie, the girl you left behind, and the Balboa Island Ferry. All are good. All are fond memories. And all are wonderful ... all in their own right.

How can anybody rate it at less than wonderful? It's not the ride as much as the experience. Enjoy one of the simplest of real life treasures reflecting a bit of a time long lost.

Fun way to cross Newport Bay

After renting beach cruiser bicycles at Newport Cruisers near the beginning of the Newport Peninsula, we took the boardwalk along the beach to the fun zone and the ferry to Balboa Island. The ferry is a fun, inexpensive way to cross the water ($1.25 per bike). Though the ride is short, it affords the opportunity to see boats of all sizes on the bay.
We had to walk our bikes (no riding) on the narrower boardwalk on Balboa but the scenic views are worth the walk. It’s not hard to find a small street to bike back to the ferry. Another exhilarating bike ride back to Newport Cruisers on comfortable bikes with baskets (and at $5 an hour) didn’t take long on the Newport Peninsula boardwalk.

Who says you can't have fun for a small amount of money?! :0)

This small ferry carries cars (up to three at a time), bikes, and pedestrians; runs continuously; and provides a great views. Parking tip: if on Balboa Island, go north on Park to Agate, park on one of the side streets, and walk to the ferry.
Rented bikes on 20th St. and road to Balboa Pier, got on the ferry, and road down to Marine St. Lovely day!

We went over to Balboa Island to just see what there was to do. Easy decision for $1...the staff was nice, efficient and didn't crash the ferry into anything...so I think that's success.

During the summer months, it does get backed up with traffic. Wait til after the morning rush or get up really early. It takes about 10 minutes to cross. I do like to see all the street lights at sunset on the island, when they come together in a single row. Just that moment of perspective is wonderfully beautiful. To watch the Seagulls float by on the soft wind, to hear the Sea Lions bark, Pelicans diving into the water trying to catch their dinner or sitting on a buoy. All these sights and sounds never do I tire of.

To get from Balboa Island to the Newport Peninsula, or vice-versa, try the Balboa Island Ferry. This is a nostalgia trip to times past. The ferry has been in existence since Newport Beach was young and still operates. It takes only THREE vehicles per ferry and crosses the narrow channel in a jiffy. You also can be a pedestrian or bicyclist to take the ferry. The ferry circumvents you having to drive your car all the way from Corona del Mar to Newport Pier and then down the long Newport/Balboa Peninsula. It takes you to the fun zone, Balboa Pier, some bayside restaurants, and the nautical museum. Warning: On extremely busy holidays, the automobile line for the ferry can be VEEEEERRRY long; best to avoid on such days unless you have a good book to read and a lot of time to wait.

Balboa Island Ferry is located in one of the most beautiful areas of the California coast. The ferry connects Balboa Island with Balboa Pennisula. You can approach the ferry from either point. The ferry is shared by cars, bikes and walkers, often with their dogs. After a pleasant walk around Balboa Island you can take the ferry across the bay to the Pennisula. A quaint fun zone adjoins the ferry entrance on the Pennisula. There are funky beach shops and lovely bay front restaurants and bars. Locals as well as tourist all enjoy the beach environment. Different water craft can be rented or chartered from this location. Summer months are crowded with visitors. Winner is more peaceful. The ferry ride is a favorite with young children.

This wonderful ferry has been transporting cars, bikes and people between the Balboa Peninsula and Balboa Island for decades. It costs $1 per person (without car or bike) and is well worth the money. The only other ways to get between the two places are to either drive all the way around, or swim. Car lines get very long at the height of the season. Then on has to calculate whether it makes sense to sit in the line for 15 minutes, or drive around in the same time. The ferry only holds three cars at a time. I usually opt for the ferry because being out on the water is such a pleasant, if short, experience. The crossing takes between one and two minutes.
